question: Question_01_(h)
statement:
You bought a rare stamp collection for 10 million dollars. The
auctioneer who sold it to you estimated its value would increase at 12\%
per year, compounded continuously. If you want to wait until the
collection has tripled in value before you sell, how many years will you
be waiting?
sols:
Let the value of the stamp collection at time \emph{t} be
\emph{v}(\emph{t}), and the time at which the collection was purchased
be time \emph{t} = 0. Then

\begin{align*}\displaystyle v(0) = 10\end{align*}

million dollars, and

\begin{align*}\displaystyle v(t) = 10 e^{0.12t}.\end{align*}

If we wait until the collection has tripled in value, then we would be
waiting until $v(t) = 30$ million dollars.

So, we solve the following equation for \emph{t}:

\begin{align*} 
30 &= 10 e^{0.12t} \\
3 &= e^{0.12t} \\
\ln(3) &= 0.12t \\
t &= \frac{\ln(3)}{0.12}\end{align*}

Therefore, we'll be waiting

\begin{align*}t = \frac{\ln(3)}{0.12}\end{align*}

years.

\textbf{Note:} This is a little more than 9 years. Also, using the rules
of logarithms, we could also express the solution as

\begin{align*}\displaystyle t = \ln(3^{25/3})\end{align*}

Whether this simplification would be necessary is up to your instructor.
hints:
Which formula would you use to calculate continuously compounded
interest? Once you have that formula, which variable are you solving
for?
